title: Fake business invoice scams (lookalike logos, ABNs, email spoofing)
summary: Scammers copy branding (logos/ABNs) and send invoices that look legit but route payments to them.
how_it_works: Scammer impersonates a real business you dealt with recently.
They send an invoice email that looks real, often with copied branding.
Payment details are changed so your money goes to the scammer.
warning_signs: Invoice arrives unexpectedly or from a slightly different email address.
example_hooks: “Our bank details have changed—please pay this one to the new account.”
what_to_do: Confirm payment details via a known phone number.
Don’t rely on email-only changes to bank details.

quick_quiz.q: What’s the safest way to get to the real website?
choices: Click the link in the message
Type the website address yourself or use the official app
Reply and ask them for another link
quick_quiz.explain: Scam messages often include links to fake sites. Typing the address yourself (or using the official app) reduces that risk.

quick_quiz.q: A message says you must act 'within 24 hours' or you'll lose access. What should you do first?
choices: Stop and verify using official contact details you find yourself
Forward it to friends to ask
quick_quiz.explain: Urgency is a classic pressure tactic. Verify using trusted contact details.
